questions.text: Sorghum causes pellagra due to the presence of:

A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining of sharp, stabbing chest pain beneath the sternum. Jugular veins are distended and enlarged during inspiration (Kussmaul sign). Imaging confirms the existence of a pericardial tamponade. Blood pressure is 105/55 mm Hg during expiration and 90/40 mm Hg during inspiration (pulsus paradoxus). Pulse is 85/min, and respiration rate is 22/min and shallow. The patient is anxious, and cognitive abilities are slightly impaired. All heart sounds are muffled. A pericardial rub can be heard on the lower left sternal border. Pericardiocentesis was performed under echocardiographic guidance. 300 mL of fluid was removed, relieving the symptoms. The patient was admitted to the hospital for treatment and observation. The major cardiovascular benefit of the pericardiocentesis was an increase in which of the following?

A 70-year-old woman, admitted 3 days earlier to the cardiac care unit after angioplasty, has gone into renal failure. Serial imaging with a contrast agent indicates that one of the three vessels is again stenosing. The patient was diagnosed 5 years ago with non–insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (type 2), which has been managed with diet and exercise. Plasma analysis shows elevations in blood urea nitrogen and creatinine, increasing progressively with each daily measurement and reaching 50% above normal by day 3. Urinalysis shows muddy brown epithelial cell casts and debris. Urine production is 300 mL/day (oliguria). Fractional excretion of sodium is 3%, and urine osmolality is 200 mOsm/kg. Abnormal renal epithelial tubular cell function is BEST indicated by which of the following?
questions.correct_answer: D. Fractional excretion of sodium of 3%

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of difficulty breathing. The patient suffered a myocardial infarction involving the anterior wall of the left ventricle 6 months earlier. The patient indicates that he has difficulty sleeping when lying down, which has been getting worse over the past month. Inspiratory crackles are present, particularly at the base of the lungs. Chest radiograph: blurry fluid build-up in the lung space appearing in a typical “butterfly” shape. Vital signs: T 37°C, P 80/min, R 26/min and shallow, BP 100/65 mm Hg. Inspiratory crackles are present, particularly at the base of the lungs. ECG: Normal sinus rhythm, evidence of past myocardial infarction. Ultrasonography: Enlarged left atrium and pulmonary vein. Pulse oximetry: 70% at arrival, 97% after beginning supplemental O2. Which of the following gas exchange defects is contributing to the patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Impaired oxygen exchange because of the low oxygen gradient between the alveoli and the pulmonary capillaries

options.label: B
options.text: Impaired oxygen exchange because of the low solubility of oxygen in interstitial fluid

options.label: C
options.text: Impaired oxygen exchange because of the decreased distance between the alveolar air and the capillary

options.label: D
options.text: Impaired carbon dioxide exchange because of the decrease in surface area

questions.correct_answer: B. Impaired oxygen exchange because of the low solubility of oxygen in interstitial fluid

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is referred to the hospital because of high calcium levels found during treatment for a fracture of her femur, which was fractured at the midshaft by a compression. The injury should not have been severe enough to break the bone. During treatment, the patient was noted to have high calcium levels and was referred for further study. The patient appears healthy and exercised regularly before the injury. The left femur is immobilized, and the injury appears to be healing well. Vital signs: T 37°C, P 80/min, R 15/min, BP 116/76 mm Hg, BMI 26. Plasma analysis showed the following: Serum calcium: 14.2 mg/dL (normal: 8.4-10.2 mg/dL) Serum phosphorus (inorganic): 2.1 mg/dL (normal: 3.0-4.5 mg/dL) PTH levels: 2200 pg/mL (normal: 230-630 pg/mL) These data indicate that the bone weakness was caused by which of the following?

A 38-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of abdominal cramping and diarrhea. The patient has a 20-year history of alcohol abuse. He is complaining over the past 6 months of passing pale and malodorous stools that are difficult to flush. Vital signs: T 37°C, P 72/min, R 15/min, BP 120/80 mm Hg. The patient is malnourished, and his liver appears cirrhotic. There is jaundice of the sclera. Plasma analysis shows: Plasma K: 3.3 mEq/L Serum calcium: 1.9 mEq/L (normal: 2.1-2.8 mEq/L) pH: 7.30 HCO3 −: 18 mEq/L (normal: 22-28 mEq/L) Serum triglyceride: 30 mg/dL (normal: 35-160 mg/dL) Cholesterol: 130 mg/dL (normal: < 200mg/dL) Fecal analysis: positive for fat The patient’s acid base disturbance is characterized as which of the following?

A 19-year-old college student comes to student health services complaining of a sporadic loss of memory. The periods of amnesia occur while he is awake and occasionally in class. During those times, his classmates report that he begins smacking his lips and fumbling around, disrupting the class. When confronted by his teacher, he has no recollection of those events and is confused and disoriented. He rests for about 30 minutes and then feels fine. The student did suffer a head injury while playing sports 6 months earlier but does not indicate any cognitive defects. Vital signs: T 37°C, P 76/min, R 18/min, BP 118/76 mm Hg. The patient is evaluated for epilepsy. The EEG tracing indicates waves of moderate amplitude and frequency of 8 to 12 waves per second. This tracing is indicative of which of the following?
Alkaline pyrogallol test helps to differentiate between
questions.correct_answer: B. Air embolism and putrefactive gases

A preterm, 28 weeks, 1000gms, has respiratory distress. There is seen-saw breathing, marked lower chest retractions and xiphoid retractions, with audible grunting, marked flaring Silverman score is
Which of the following is not a parameter in Downe’s scoring?
What is the best approach for managing a 28 wks baby, 800gms in delivery room?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ • In the past administration of surfactant into the trachea of symptomatic premature infants immediately after birth (prophylactic) or during the 1st few hr of life (early rescue) showed reduced air leak and mortality from RDS.
  • ↳ • CPAP started at birth is as effective as prophylactic or early surfactant and is the approach of choice for the delivery room management of a preterm neonate at risk for RDS.
  • ↳ • Early use of CPAP for stabilization of at-risk preterm infants beginning as early as in the delivery room reduces ventilator needs.

questions.text: Children 6 to 59 months of age may be discharged from treatment when they meet either of the following anthropometric criteria:

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: Weight-for-age Z-score (WHZ) >-3 and no edema for at least one to two weeks

questions.correct_answer: A. Weight-for height Z-score (WHZ) >-2 and no edema for at least one to two weeks

questions.text: During fetal life, the coronary and cerebral arteries are perfused exclusively from
What % of RV outflow enters the pulmonary circulation during fetal life?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ • Fetal superior vena cava blood, which is considerably less oxygenated (Po2 of 12-14 mmHg), enters the right atrium and preferentially flows across the tricuspid valve, rather than the foramen ovale, into the right ventricle.
  • ↳ • From the right ventricle, the blood is ejected into the pulmonary artery. Because the pulmonary arterial circulation is vasoconstricted only approximately 5% of right ventricular outflow enters the lungs. The major portion of this blood bypasses the lungs and flows right-to-left through the ductus arteriosus into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the fetal body, including providing flow to the placenta via the 2 umbilical arteries.
  • ↳ • Thus, the upper part of the fetal body (including the coronary and cerebral arteries and those to the upper extremities) is perfused exclusively from the left ventricle with blood that has a slightly higher Po2 than the blood perfusing the lower part of the fetal body, which is derived mostly from the right ventricle.
  • ↳ • Only a small volume of blood from the ascending aorta (10% of fetal cardiac output) flows all the way around the aortic arch (aortic isthmus) to the descending aorta.

questions.text: What is the sequence of congenital heart disease in Down’s syndrome is descending order of prevalence?

options.label: A

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: A. Complete atrioventricular septal defect (CAVSD)>VSD>ASD>Partial atrioventricular septal defect (PAVSD)>TOF

On sterile speculum examination,the patient has a pool of clear fluid in the vagina that is nitrazine and fern positive. She is contracting every 3 to 4 minutes, and her cervix on visualization appears to be dilated 2 to 3 cm. Which of the following is the best course of action?

A 34-yrs-old woman, G0, has been trying to get pregnant for the last 3 years.On pelvic examination, you palpate a nodular, tender uterosacral ligament, a retroverted but normal-sized uterus, and a right adnexal mass. A recent pelvic ultrasound reveals a 6-cm right complex ovarian mass. Her CA-125 is elevated. What is the initial next step in management?

A 21-year-old G1 P0 at 42 weeks' gestation presents with mild contractions every 4 to 5 minutes and a cervical examination of 1 cm dilation, 50% effaced at -2 station. The fetal heart rate tracing reveals a baseline in the 140s with repetitive variable decelerations. The patient has had routine prenatal care and a normal fetal survey at 18 weeks' gestation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these decelerations?

On postoperative day 1, the patient complains of numbness in her medial thigh. Which of the following is the most likely etiology for this clinical presentation?

During the routine examination of the umbilical cord and placenta after a spontaneous vaginal delivery, you notice that the baby had only one umbilical artery. Which of the following is true regarding the finding of a single umbilical artery?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a rare finding in singleton pregnancies and is therefore not significant.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an indicator of an increased incidence of congenital anomalies of the fetus.

options.label: C
options.text: It is equally common in newborns of diabetic and non-diabetic mothers.

options.label: D
options.text: It is present in 5% of all births

questions.correct_answer: B. It is an indicator of an increased incidence of congenital anomalies of the fetus.

questions.text: A patient presents for her first prenatal visit at 26 weeks and is found to have twins on ultrasound examination. The largest pocket around twin A is 9.6cm and around twin B IS 2 cm. what is the most likely cause of these findings

A 36-year-old G1P0 at 35 weeks gestation presents to labor and delivery complaining of a several-day history of generalized malaise, anorexia, nausea, and emesis. She denies any headache or visual changes. Her fetal movement has been good, and she denies any regular uterine contractions, vaginal bleeding, or rupture of membranes. On physical examination, you notice that she is mildly jaundiced and appears to be a little confused. Her vital signs indicate a temperature of 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse of 70 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 100/62 mm Hg. Blood is drawn and the following results are obtained: SGOT/SGPT 334/386, serum ammonia 65, glucose 68, creat 2.2, PT/PTT 16/50sec, Urinalysis is positive for 3+ protein and large ketones. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 48 year old man with type 1 diabetes of 30 years’ duration attends clinic for routine review. He is on a basal-bolus insulin regimen and has an HbA1c of 8.6%. He is on no other medication. Blood pressure is 155/92 mmHg (repeated 3 times with similar results) and he has microalbuminuria. Estimated glomerular filtration rate is 54 mL/min/1.73 m2. A 56 year old man is referred to the endocrinology clinic with a history of poor libido and erectile dysfunction. Blood tests reveal total testosterone 5.6 nmol/L (162 ng/dL), SHBG 42.1 nmol/L (4.00 µg/mL), FSH 2.1 IU/L (0.5 µg/L) and LH 1.76 IU/L (0.2 µg/L). He has no other past medical history of note and has not fathered any children. On examination visual fields are normal, testes are 5 mL volume and soft on palpation. He has little in the way of pubic or axillary hair. He has not noticed any problem with his sense of smell. Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?

A 25 year old female presented with multiple episodes of syncopal attacks even at rest.Past history is significant for sarcoidosis diagnosed one month back.She is not started on steroids as she was having Scadding stage 1 at that time.On examination pulse is irregular with occasional long pauses,BP-110/80 mmHg,chest is clear,CVS-irregular heart rate,no cardiac murmur noticed.ECG done is shown in the figure. Identify the following rhythm in the ECG?
questions.correct_answer: C. Mobitz type II AV block

questions.text: An 18-year-old male military recruit reports several episodes of palpitation and syncope over the past several years.On examination-puse rate -84/min,BP-130/80 mmHg,CVS-S1 is loud,S2 is widely split,no cardiac murmur observed.Chest is clear. His ECG is shown in the following figure.

A 30-year-old male continues to have elevated blood pressure of 180/100 despite therapeutic doses of hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, amlodipine, and metoprolol. He has had persistent hypokalemia despite taking KCl 20 mEq twice daily. He does not use illicit drugs or over the-counter medications. He is compliant with his antihypertensive regimen. He has a BMI of 23; thyroid examination is normal, and no abdominal bruit is appreciated. Routine blood chemistry show: Sodium: 145 mEq/L Chloride: 110 mEq/L Potassium: 3.0 mEq/L HCO3 : 30 mEq/L Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL Glucose: 90 mg/dL Which of the following is the best next step?

options.label: D
options.text: Plasma aldosterone to plasma renin activity ratio

questions.correct_answer: D. Plasma aldosterone to plasma renin activity ratio

questions.text: A patient presented with loss of memory with difficulty in managing money,driving,following instructions, forgetting names.There is no history of stroke,head injury or use of alcohol.There is no past history of thyroid disease,diabetes or hypertension.On examination there are no signs of hemiplegia or peripheral neuropathy. All of the following can be a cause of dementia EXCEPT:

A 62-year-old man with underlying COPD develops a viral upper respiratory infection and begins taking an over-the-counter decongestant. Shortly thereafter he experiences palpitations and presents to the emergency room, where the following rhythm strip is obtained.
questions.correct_answer: C. Atrial flutter with 4:1 atrioventricular block

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is evaluated by her primary care physician because she is concerned that she may have systemic lupus erythematosus. She has no significant past medical history, and her only medication is occasional ibuprofen. She reports that she has had intermittent oral ulcers and right knee pain. Physical examination shows no evidence of alopecia, skin rash, or joint swelling/inflammation. Her blood work shows that she has a positive antinuclear antibody at a titre of 1:40, but no other abnormalities. Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Four diagnostic criteria are required to be diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus; this patient has three.

options.label: B
options.text: Four diagnostic criteria are required to be diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus; this patient has two.

options.label: C
options.text: If a urinalysis shows proteinuria, she will meet criteria for systemic lupus erythematosus.

options.label: D
options.text: She meets criteria for systemic lupus erythematosus because she has three criteria for disease.

questions.correct_answer: B. Four diagnostic criteria are required to be diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus; this patient has two.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with pain in her hands for last one year. The joints involved are metacarpophalangeal joints and metatarsophalangeal joints. She has difficulty moving the joints when getting out of bed or after staying in one position too long. The pain is worse in the morning, but improves as she starts to move around over the course of the day over the next 1 to 2 hours. She also complains of dyspnea on exertion. Lab test-CRP: elevated, RA factor-positive and anti-CCP: positive. In view of dyspnea chest x ray was also done. All of the following pulmonary radiographic findings may be explained by her rheumatologic condition EXCEPT:

A 35-year-old woman with progressive immobility of her fingers and tightening of her face. She also complains of shortness of breath. Past medical history-Hypertension. On examination-BP-150/100 mmHg, Chest: fine crepitations present, Extremities: sclerodactyly, edema of lower extremities, Skin: tightening at face and hand and telangiectasia present. Which of the following is nearly twice as common in patients with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis than in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis?

A 55-year-old obese woman presents with pressure-like substernal chest pain lasting 1 hour. On examination, the patient is pale and diaphoretic. Blood pressure is 90/50 and heart rate is 50 beats/min. Lungs are clear, but the jugular column is elevated to 10 cm above the sternal angle. ECG is shown in the following figure.
Clinical features of Turner syndrome include all EXCEPT:
questions.correct_answer: B. Narrow carrying angle of Elbow

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with aching and stiffness in the trunk, hip, and shoulders. There is widespread muscle pain after mild exertion. Symptoms are worse in the morning and improve during the day. They are also worsened by stress. The patient is always tired and exhausted. She has trouble sleeping at night. On examination, joints are normal. ESR is normal, and Lyme antibody and HIV test are negative. The patient has multiple tender points to palpation on physical examination.What is the likely diagnosis?
All of the following statements are true EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Dorsal column fibres synapse at the cuneate and gracile nuclei

options.label: B
options.text: Pain and temperature sensations are carried by lateral spinothalamic tract

options.label: C
options.text: Spinal cord ends at lower level of 5th lumbar vertebrae

options.label: D
options.text: Dorsal spinocerebellar tract carries fibres from the same side of the body

questions.correct_answer: C. Spinal cord ends at lower level of 5th lumbar vertebrae

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is found unconscious at home by her daughter. The daughter last spoke to her mother 1 day ago, at which time her mother seemed fine. The patient has diabetes, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and chronic back pain. Her medications include metformin, lisinopril, warfarin, and oxycodone. On examination her blood pressure is 167/70, pulse 48 beats/min, respiratory rate 12 breaths/min and irregular, and temperature 37.2°C. There is no neck rigidity.The patient does not respond to verbal stimuli. Pupils are equally reactive to light. The oculocephalic reflex (doll’s eye maneuver) is normal. On applying firm pressure to the orbital rim, the patient flexes her right arm, but does not move her left arm. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Lacunar infarct in the right internal capsule

questions.text: A 70-year-old intensive care unit patient complains of fever and shaking chills. The patient develops hypotension, and blood cultures are positive for gram-negative bacilli. The patient begins bleeding from venepuncture sites and around his Foley catheter. Laboratory studies are as follows: Hct: 38% WBC: 15,000/?L Platelet count: 40,000/?L(normal 150,000-400,000) Peripheral blood smear: fragmented RBCs PT: elevated PTT: elevated Plasma fibrinogen: 70 mg/dL(normal 200-400) What is the most likely explanation of this clinical picture?

A 30-year-old male took prophylaxis for malaria. Three days after beginning treatment, he develops pallor, fatigue, and jaundice. Hematocrit is 30% (it had been 43%) and reticulocyte count is 7%. He stops taking the medication. The next step in treatment should consist of which of the following?

A 38-year-old woman presents with repeated episodes of sore throat. She is on no medications, does not use ethanol, and has no history of renal disease. Physical examination is normal. Hb is 9.0 g/dL, MCV is 85 fL(normal), white blood cell count is 2000/?L, and platelet count is 30,000/?L. Which of the following is the best approach to diagnosis?

You evaluate a 48-year-old man for chronic renal insufficiency. He has a history of hypertension, osteoarthritis, and gout. He currently has no complaints. His medical regimen includes lisinopril 40 mg daily, hydro-chlorothiazide 25 mg daily, allopurinol 300 mg daily, and acetaminophen for his joint pains. Examination shows BP 146/86, pulse 76, a soft S4 gallop, and mild peripheral edema. There is no abdominal bruit. His urinalysis reveals 1+ proteinuria and no cellular elements. Serum creatinine is 2.2 mg/dL and his estimated GFR is 42 mL/min. What is the most important step in preventing progression of his renal disease?

options.label: B
options.text: Adding a calcium channel blocker to improve blood pressure control.

options.label: C
options.text: Obtaining a CT renal arteriogram to exclude renal artery stenosis.

questions.correct_answer: B. Adding a calcium channel blocker to improve blood pressure control.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presented with the acute onset of severe pain in the great toe of his right foot that developed over a few hours. He had one episode like this 2 months ago.He takes alcohol daily and is taking non vegetarian meals. On examination- Great toe of right foot is warm, red, and extremely tender. Lab Reports: serum creatinine 1.5 mg/dL, serum uric acid level: 7.6 mg/dL. All the following medicines can be used

A 70-year-old man known case of type 2 diabetes and hypertension comes to OPD with increasing fatigue and tingling sensation in his feet for last one month. He is consuming alcohol 300 ml/day for last 40 years. He is taking ramipril and metformin. Physical Examination: pallor present, Cardiovascular: normal, Chest: clear. Neurological: decreased sensation symmetrically over the lower extremities bilaterally; reduced position and vibratory sensation. On Lab tests-Hb 9.0 g/dl, peripheral smear-macrocytes seen, serum vitamin B12 level: low, Folate: normal, fasting plasma Glucose: 185 mg/dL, HbA1c: 8.0%.What can be the cause of patient’s symptoms?

An 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his father with a 2-day history of swelling in his hands and ankles. The father states that about 2 weeks ago the boy had been sick with fever and complaining of a sore throat. They didn’t visit the doctor at that time because the boy felt better after 2 days without antimicrobial treatment. Now his urine has a specific color as shown in the image. The boy’s temperature is 37.1°C and his blood pressure is 210/140 mm Hg. Physical demonstrates signi?cant edema of the hands, wrists, feet, and ankles. A urine specimen is collected and results are given below: • Urinalysis–Dipstick : Blood: positive, Protein: positive, Leukocyte esterase: negative & Nitrite: negative. Which of the following is most likely directly involved in the development of the boy’s current condition?

A 25-year-old man visits his physician because of a sore on his penis. He states the sore does not hurt, but he is concerned because it has been present for about 2 weeks. He has not travelled outside of the country. His temperature is 37.1°C and his pulse is 85 beats per minute. Physical examination reveals a single, indurated ulcer with well-demarcated edges on the penile shaft. No urethral discharge is noted. Mild inguinal lymphadenopathy is observed, and the lymph nodes are ?rm and nontender. The Physician suspected a STI and ordered VDRL and TPPA and both are reactive with high titers. After the diagnosis is con?rmed the man is treated with penicillin. Twenty-four hours after starting the antibiotic he develops an abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, and myalgia. His temperature is 38.9°C and his pulse is 154 beats per minute. Which other pathogen is also associated with this antibiotic reaction?

A 30-year-old pregnant woman, 8 weeks gestation, works as a maid in a orphanage and takes care of a 5-year-old boy. The boy has a slight fever and is more tired than normal. A few days later, the woman notices a pinpoint, ?at, red rash on the boy’s face and seems to be more prevalent on his cheeks. She returns to work 3 days later and notices the boy now has a rash on his stomach, arms, and legs as shown in the image. The pediatrician examine the boy and gave a diagnosis of Papular-purpuric gloves and socks syndrome due to a viral etiology. The woman’s baby is at greatest risk for developing which of the following condition?
A women in reproductive age group plant to have Rubella vaccine prepared from RA27/3 strain. She plan to have her pregnancy. All the following statements are true regarding this vaccine except

options.label: A
options.text: This vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

options.label: B
options.text: Pregnancy should be avoided at least for 4 weeks (28 days) following vaccination.

options.label: C
options.text: If a woman conceives <4 weeks following vaccination, immediate termination of pregnancy is required

options.label: D
options.text: Infants below 1 year should not be vaccinated.

questions.correct_answer: C. If a woman conceives <4 weeks following vaccination, immediate termination of pregnancy is required

questions.text: An 18-year-old female college student is hospitalized because of high fever, headache, and skin rash. She has had these symptoms for the past 24 hours. She has a history of recurrent infections, including bacterial meningitis 6 months ago that was successfully treated with ceftriaxone. She takes no medication at home. She denies recent travel and insect bites. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Her temperature is 39.10C, blood pressure is 104/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 110/min and regular. General physical examination reveals a petechial rash on the trunk and extremities, including the palms and soles. Neurologic examination shows lethargy, alertness, ?uent speech, and ability to follow commands. She has evidence of neck stiffness and photophobia. Which of the following immune system impairments is the most likely explanation for her symptoms?

options.label: D
options.text: Inability to form the membrane attack complex

questions.correct_answer: D. Inability to form the membrane attack complex

questions.text: A 26-year-old man returns to the emergency department after developing a fever and skin rash. The patient was discharged from the hospital 10 days ago after treatment for a copperhead snake bite to his left leg. He received multiple doses of polyvalent Fab antivenom therapy and other supportive care during hospitalization. The patient's bite site pain, swelling, and ecchymosis have resolved; however, he has developed fever, pain in multiple extremity joints, and pruritic rash over the past 2 days. He has no chronic medical conditions. Temperature is 38.50 C , blood pressure is 128/70 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 17/min. Physical examination shows a diffuse urticarial rash. No mucous membrane lesions are present. There is tenderness to palpation of the bilateral metacarpophalangeal joints, wrists, and ankles with no redness or swelling. Blood cell counts, serum chemistry studies, and coagulation parameters are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's current condition?

options.label: A
options.text: lgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction to the antivenom

options.label: C
options.text: Snake venom-induced diffuse mast cell degranulation

options.label: D
options.text: Tissue deposition of host antibodies and antivenom complexes

questions.correct_answer: D. Tissue deposition of host antibodies and antivenom complexes

questions.text: A neonate born to a 26-year-old woman is evaluated in the newborn nursery. The patient was delivered vaginally at 38 weeks gestation, and Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Initial evaluation shows hydrocephalus, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly. Funduscopic examination reveals retinal exudates and scarring. Histopathologic evaluation of the placenta shows in?ltration of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages, as well as many areas of calci?cation. Within the placental tissue, there are numerous intracellular, crescent-shaped organisms with a central nucleus. Which of the following maternal interventions would have been most effective in preventing this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Avoidance of consumption of undercooked meat

options.label: C
options.text: Consumption of unpasteurized cow's milk products

options.label: D
options.text: Strict avoidance of mosquitoes during pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: B. Avoidance of consumption of undercooked meat

questions.text: A 13—year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to a change in behavior. His special education teacher reported that for the last several weeks he has frequently taken off his shoes to scratch his feet during class. The patient has a history of learning disability but is otherwise healthy. Examination shows erythema and excoriations between the toes of both feet. Microscopy of skin scrapings from the rash is shown in the image. Which of the following antimicrobial drugs is likely to be the most effective against the pathogen causing this patient's condition?

A 46-year-old woman comes to the of?ce to be tested for HlV after one of her prior sexual partners found that he was HIV-positive. She feels healthy and has no symptoms. The patient has never had a sexually transmitted infection and has no chronic medical conditions. She has had several sexual partners in her lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. HIV antigen-antibody immunoassay and a con?rmatory HIV-1 antibody test are positive. Further studies reveal plasma HIV viral load is >250,000 copies/mL and CD4 lymphocyte count is 150 cells/mm3. After discussing the results and need for treatment, the patient agrees to start antiretroviral therapy. An additional medication to prevent opportunistic infections is also planned. This added treatment is most likely being used to prevent infection from which of the following pathogens?

A conjugal mating experiment that was performed using two di?erent strains of Escherichia coli resulted in the production of an F? (prime) strain. The series of events that most likely preceded formation of this strain would be:

options.label: B
options.text: Formation of an Hfr followed by an Hfr × F¯ mating

options.label: D
options.text: Resolution of an Hfr followed by an F? (prime) × F¯ mating

questions.correct_answer: D. Resolution of an Hfr followed by an F? (prime) × F¯ mating

questions.text: A lumbar epidural catheter placed in healthy 23 year old gravida 1 para 0 parturient for elective LSCS. After few minutes of full local anaesthetic dose administered she complains of dullness in oral cavity and diplopia. most likely explanation for this is

options.label: A
options.text: Total spinal from inadverant subarachnoid injection of local anaesthetic

questions.text: A 28 year old male is planned for laparotomy for perforation peritonitis. Anaesthesia is induced with propofol 2mg/kg and rocuronium .9 mg/kg along with controlled ventilation.The least efficient circut would be

A sexually active wife of a long distance truck driver presented with copious vaginal discharge of 2 days duration. She presents to the primary health worker and reports burning sensation and itching on the genitals. She is also washing the area frequently which gives her relief. According to the syndromal management of vaginal discharge, which of the following would be given to her?

A 7 years old boy presented with painful swelling on the scalp. His friend also seems to have a similar issue in school. His mother reports balding at a few spots on the scalp. o/e- There is purulent swelling of the scalp and lymph nodes enlarged in occipital region. Which one of the following would be most helpful for diagnostic evaluation?
A 1-year-old child presents with eczematous dermatitis over the extensor surfaces. His mother has a history of bronchial asthma. What should be the most probable diagnosis?

A patient presents with oral and genital ulcers since 6 months. She is unable to eat well due to it and now is losing weight. She also reports hair loss probably due to poor nutrition. Her skin has started to ulcerate and she feels pain in the raw skin lesions. She reports that all the raw areas were previously blisters to start with. Her biopsy was done and sent for immunofluorescence. The report is positive for fluorescence. The diagnosis is:
A young man presents with asymptomatic macules and erythematous painless lesion over palms and soles with generalised lymphadenopathy and oral lesions. Treatment of choice in this condition:
An elevated SP : AP ratio can be seen in which of the following? I. Endolymphatic hydrops II. Cerebellar infarction III. SSCD IV. Tensor tympani myoclonus

During an initial surgery for an extensive cholesteatoma that involved the ossicular chain and surrounding structures, you were able to clear all visible disease. At the time of a second-look procedure, where would be the most likely location you would expect to find recidivistic disease?
A Cocaine addict patient came to ENT department with epistaxis whenever he clears his nasal crusts. What is the most likely cause of epistaxis?
Facial paralysis with ear canal edema as shown in the given image and underlying deep facial pain in an elderly diabetic patient is due to?

options.label: B
options.text: Basal cell cancer of the ear canal

questions.text: Which is the most accurate statement regarding the etiology and management of Ramsay Hunt syndrome (RHS)?

options.label: A
options.text: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) reactivation at the geniculate ganglion and is treated with antivirals only

options.label: B
options.text: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) reactivation at the geniculate ganglion and is treated with corticosteroids only

options.label: C
options.text: VZV reactivation at the geniculate ganglion and is treated with antivirals only

options.label: D
options.text: VZV reactivation at the geniculate ganglion and is treated with antivirals and corticosteroids

questions.correct_answer: D. VZV reactivation at the geniculate ganglion and is treated with antivirals and corticosteroids

questions.text: Which of the following is true of a type III laryngeal cleft?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an interarytenoid defect that extends inferiorly no further than the level of the true vocal folds.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a total cricoid cleft that extends completely through the cricoid cartilage with or without extension into the cervical trachea.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a defect that partially involves the cricoid lamina with extension of the cleft below the level of the true vocal folds.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a defect extending into the posterior wall of the thoracic trachea extending as far as the carina.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is a total cricoid cleft that extends completely through the cricoid cartilage with or without extension into the cervical trachea.

questions.text: While surgical removal of Impacted fish bone, the surgeon has accidentally injured internal laryngeal nerve. What is the possible site of impaction of fish bone?
A 14 years boy presents with nasal obstruction, proptosis (Fig),recurrent epistaxis from 3–4 years not responding to anterior nasal packing.

options.label: A
options.text: Digital palpation should be never done before operation.

questions.correct_answer: B. Embolization alone should be done

questions.text: A 7 year old previously healthy female presents with a 12 day history of persistent thick nasal discharge, nasal congestion, cough, and intermittent low grade fever. On further questioning, her parents reveal that the cough is worse at night but there is no wheezing, currently or in the past. She also seems to have one temperature spike daily to about 38.2 degrees (100.8 degrees F). She is not taking any medications. They deny the possibility of a nasal foreign body. She denies any vomiting, headache, earache, or rashes.Her past medical history is negative for hospitalizations, asthma, allergic rhinitis, or cystic fibrosis.Her tympanic membranes are clear. She has nasal congestion with thick yellow purulent mucus in the posterior nasal pharynx. Her nasal turbinates are red and swollen. She has mild tenderness to palpation of her maxillary sinuses.Choose the most appropriate statements regarding diagnosis: I. Pain is limited to the area overlying the affected sinus. II. Edema of the overlying tissues is commoner in children. III. Mucopurulent nasal discharge is necessary to make the diagnosis. IV. Decongestant nose drops are used to provide 'medical drainage'. V. An antibiotic solution should be instilled into the sinus cavity during antral lavage.

A patient of suspected sinusitis has undergone CT scan of sinuses. The radiologist reports an anatomical variation of posterior ethmoid air cell lying in close proximity to optic nerve. Identify the cell?

A 49-year-old obese man recently diagnosed with vasospas- tic angina started a treatment with nifedipine. The drug has a volume of distribution (Vd) of about 55 L in a 70-kg person, but in this obese patient, the Vd turned out to be 110 L. The standard loading dose of nifedipine for a patient weighing 70 kg is 30 mg. Which of the following should be the thera- peutic loading dose administered to this patient (in mg) in order to achieve the same target concentration?

A 52-year-old man underwent liver biopsy for a suspected liver cancer. Conscious sedation was induced with a drug combination that has the advantage of being reversible by the administration of specific receptor antagonists. Which of the following pairs of drugs was most likely administered?

A 7-year-old boy was brought by his mother to his family pediatrician because he still wet the bed. The boy achieved daytime bladder control by 3 years of age but wet his bed once or twice a week. A conditioning therapy with the aid of a bell and pad alarm, started 2 weeks previously, was only partially effective. The pediatrician ordered a drug to be given by nasal spray. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?

A female taking ART, complains of migraine since last 4 days she took ergotamine for treatment, now complains of tingling and pain in toe upwards till mid thigh. Examination shows no pulse in dorsalis pedis and popliteal artery. What might be cause?
Patient of ischaemic stroke was given Clopidogrel. But still after 6 months had another attack of stroke. Genetic deficiency of which enzyme is responsible for failure of Clopidogrel therapy.

An old age patient undergoing treatment for cancer (cisplatin, cytarabine) presented with fever. Lab investigations revealed Hb-9 g/dl, Absolute neutrophil count- 450/mm3, low platelets. Treatment with which Antimicrobial should be avoided ?
A 50 year old man, who had a recent history of valve replacement surgery in on anticoagulants and develops the below lesion. Which of the following is responsible for the same ?
An HIV+ female on ART develops weight gain, breast hypertrophy, hyperglycemia, increase LDL levels and renal stones. She is likely to be taking:

Paediatrician was called for attending a new born baby. The serum unconjugated bilirubin of this baby was 33 mg/dL. Which of the following drug taken by mother in late 3rd trimester may have lead to this problem?
Drug of choice for acute treatment of ECG abnormality

An 8 year old child presents with hip pain and limping gait. He is unable to walk and has high grade fever with chills. All blood counts are elevated. On examination following is the attitude of the hip. What’s the most probable diagnosis ?
Which of the following is NOT true about management of the condition shown in the image ?

options.label: A
options.text: Fulcrum of manipulation is Head of Talus

options.label: B
options.text: Aim of manipulation is Talonavicular Joint Reduction

options.label: D
options.text: Cavus is the most common deformity to reoccur

questions.correct_answer: D. Cavus is the most common deformity to reoccur

questions.text: Identify the fracture and most common nerve injured with this.
Identify the instrument shown in the image below :

A 22 year old male presents with fracture shaft humerus after an RTA. On examination he is able to extend his wrist. He was taken up for plaster but post that he is unable to extend his wrist. Which is the next step in management ?

options.label: B
options.text: Removal of plaster and wait for recovery of nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Removal of plaster and re plaster in another appropriate position

options.label: D
options.text: Don’t remove plaster as the nerve will repair on its own

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has a 5-cm RCC in the upper pole of a solitary left kidney and a single 2-cm left lower lung metastasis. What is the best treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Simultaneous radical nephrectomy and pulmonary lobectomy

options.label: C
options.text: Staged partial nephrectomy and pulmonary lobectomy

options.label: D
options.text: Simultaneous partial nephrectomy and pulmonary lobectomy

questions.correct_answer: D. Simultaneous partial nephrectomy and pulmonary lobectomy

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is seen for evaluation of recurrent nephrolithiasis. He has spontaneously passed three stones over the previous 4 years and has recently undergone shockwave lithotripsy twice without success. He has been treated in the past with an unknown medication, but this was discontinued because the parents believed it was of no benefit. Urinalysis demonstrates hexagonal crystals. The likely metabolic diagnosis contributing to this patient's recurrent stone formation is:
Which of the following classification in biliary injury also includes vascular injury?
A 24-year-old man had a CT scan 36 hours after a motor vehicle accident. The most likely diagnosis is:

A 30 yr old female presented with abdominal pain and lump. USG reavealed a mass arising from liver. CECT shows the following picture. All of the following are true about this malignant tumour of the liver except:

A 30-year-old man has gross hematuria and cystoscopy reveals a papillary tumor. Transurethral resection of the tumor reveals a noninvasive 2-cm papillary low-malignant-potential urothelial tumor. Muscle is present in the resected specimen. All of the tumor is resected. The best treatment is:

options.label: B
options.text: Repeat cystoscopy with random bladder biopsies.

options.label: C
options.text: Radical cystectomy because of the patient's young age.

questions.correct_answer: D. Immediate mitomycin C intravesical therapy

questions.text: 55-year-old man presents with worsening cirrhosis. After evaluation by a hepatologist, he presents for evaluation for hepatic transplantation. He is informedthat prioritization for transplantation is based on the Model of End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) score, and that patientswith higher MELD scores have a greaterbenefit from transplantation. Which of the following contributes to the MELD score?

A 22-year-old woman is seen in a surgery clinic for a bulge in the right groin. She denies pain and is able to make the bulge disappear by lying down and putting steady pressure on the bulge. She has never experienced nausea or vomiting. On examination she has a reducible hernia below the inguinal ligament. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Observation for now and follow-up in surgery clinic in 6 months

options.label: B
options.text: Observation for now and follow-up in surgery clinic if she develops further symptoms

questions.correct_answer: C. Elective surgical repair of hernia

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who is 15 weeks pregnant has new onset of nausea, vomiting, and right-sided abdominal pain. She has been free of nausea since early in her first trimester. The pain has become worse over the past 6 hours. Which of the following is the most common non-obstetric surgical disease of the abdomen during pregnancy?

On colonoscopy a malignant lesion is identified 5 cm proximal to the splenic flexure. There are no contraindications to resection and the decision is made to operate with curative intent. The most appropriate procedure would be

The nursing staff asks you to review an erect chest radiograph of a 60-year-oldwoman who has undergone open colonic surgery for a pelvic mass 2 days ago.She is comfortable at rest. Her abdomen is distended, with absent bowel sounds.Chest X – ray was done. What is true about the x – ray finding?

options.label: D
options.text: A normal finding 3 days post laparotomy

questions.correct_answer: D. A normal finding 3 days post laparotomy

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is admitted following a stab injury to the right groin. He is bleeding profusely from the wound. His blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg and hispulse is 140 beats/min. He is agitated and mildly confused. His skin is cool andmottled. In this scenario, which is the best mode of fluid delivery?

options.label: C
options.text: Right internal jugular approach central line

options.label: D
options.text: Two wide-bore cannulae inserted bilaterally to the antecubitalfossae

questions.correct_answer: D. Two wide-bore cannulae inserted bilaterally to the antecubitalfossae

questions.text: A 28-year-old male motorcyclist is brought into the emergency departmentwhere you, as the doctor on call, are asked to assess his consciousness as partof the primary survey. He is unresponsive when you speak to him, but, on rubbinghis sternum, opens his eyes and tries to push your hand away. During yourassessment he also made few sounds that you are unable to understand. HisGlasgow Coma Scale score is

A 59-year-old males presents with longstanding weight loss, anorexia andlethargy. Physical examination reveals a swelling in the left supraclavicularfossa. A disseminated adenocarcinoma of the stomach is diagnosedfollowing a gastroscopy and computed tomography scan of the thorax and abdomen.This patient has presented with

A 55-year-old woman presents with a 6-cm right thyroid mass and palpable cervical lymphadenopathy. Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of one of the lymph nodes demonstrates the presence of thyroid tissue. Which of the following best describes the management of this thyroid disorder?

options.label: A
options.text: Screening for pancreatic endocrine neoplasms and hypercalcemia

options.label: B
options.text: Total thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection

options.label: C
options.text: Total thyroidectomy with frozen section intraoperatively, with modified radical neck dissection reserved for patients with extra-capsular invasion

options.label: D
options.text: Right thyroid lobectomy followed by iodine 131 (131I) therapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Total thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection

questions.text: A 60 years old patient presented with acute onset of chest pain radiating to the interscapular region. A CT scan was done. Which of the following statement regarding this condition is true?

options.label: A
options.text: This dissection can be both Stanford class A and DeBakey type I.

options.label: B
options.text: Stanford class A dissections are treated with aggressive medical management of blood pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: DeBakey type III dissections are proximal to the left subclavian artery

options.label: D
options.text: Stanford class B dissections are always considered surgical emergencies

questions.correct_answer: A. This dissection can be both Stanford class A and DeBakey type I.

questions.text: Match the following Surgical Wound Classification with the hernia repair scenario:
The test done below is done for which surgery?

A 50-year-old male presents with a right-sided slow-growing rounded neck mass located anterior to the sternocleidomastoid. The mass appears to move side to side only. CT of the neck is performed and demonstrates widening of the carotid bifurcation by a well-defined tumor blush. The mass is 3 cm. Optimal management consists of:

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical excision in a periadventitial plane

questions.correct_answer: D. Surgical excision in a periadventitial plane

questions.text: A 79-year-old female falls at home. In the ER, she is found to have a pelvic fracture with a large retroperitoneal hematoma. While waiting for angioembolization byInterventional Radiology (IR), the patient becomes hypotensive and is transfused with two units of packed red blood cells and two units of fresh-frozen plasma. After this, the patient starts to complain of shortness of breath, has desaturations, and requires intubation. Which statement best describes a transfusion-related acute lung injury(TRALI)?

options.label: A
options.text: Onset occurs 24 h after a transfusion.

options.label: B
options.text: Onset occurs most often after transfusion with freshfrozenplasma.

options.label: C
options.text: Clinical findings include dyspnea, hypertension, and bradycardia.

questions.correct_answer: B. Onset occurs most often after transfusion with freshfrozenplasma.

questions.text: Identify the knot shown in the image:
A patient of thyroid nodule, euthyroid status, underwent hemithyroidectomy. The histopathological image of the specimen is shown in the figure. This picture is characteristic of?

A 70-year-old woman presents with complaints of mouth pain while chewing and night sweats. She has had many past episodes of sialolithiasis in her parotid gland, but they often resolve spontaneously after a few days of sucking on lemon drops. Physical examination reveals a swollen right parotid gland which is later confirmed to be a pleomorphic adenoma. She undergoes a parotidectomy. Shortly after the proce- dure, she complains of numbness over her right earlobe. Which nerve was most likely injured?
questions.correct_answer: B. Branch of the cervical plexus

questions.text: A patient of portal hypertension, with history of variceal bleed 3 times, portal hypertension is refractory to medical management underwent the surgery shown in figure. Identify this shunt surgery done for portal hypertension

An 85-year-old nursing home patient is found to have a worsening stage III sacral pressure ulcer. The ulcer is debrided and tissue for culture obtained. Tissue cultures reveal 10*8 organisms per gram of tissue after operative debridement. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of the patient’s wound?

You are asked to see a 24-year-old male with no medical problems who sustained a gunshot wound to the right thigh 1h prior to arrival. He is afebrile with an HR of 136 beats/minand a BP of 90/60 mmHg. He is initially alert and asking forwater but becomes confused during your brief interview. He is in which class of hemorrhagic shock?

A 35-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and jaundice. Subsequent ERCP reveals the congenital cystic anomaly of her biliary system illustrated in the film shown here. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Cholecystectomy with resection of the extrahepatic biliary tract and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

questions.correct_answer: A. Cholecystectomy with resection of the extrahepatic biliary tract and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady is being worked up for an elective cholecystectomy. She doesn’t have any complains apart from right hypochondrial pain. She has undergone a LSCS 2 years back without any complications. General physical examination is within normal limits. Her coagulation profile shows Prothrombin time of 15 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time of 56 seconds, platelet count of 188000/cu.mm. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man has noted cramping abdominal pain for the past year associated with fever, easy fatigue, and low-volume diarrhoea. On physical examination, there is right lower quadrant tenderness. Bowel sounds are present. His stool is positive for occult blood. A colonoscopy reveals mucosal edema and ulceration in the terminal ileum, but the transverse and descending portions of the colon are not affected. Peripheral blood examination shows large oval RBC with hyper segmented neutrophils. Laboratory studies show serum anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies. An ileal biopsy is likely to show.
A 22-year-old known case of Marfan syndrome has been detected a diastolic murmur in the aortic region which of the following is a likely complication of the cardiac manifestation of this patient?

A 10-year-old boy is diagnosed of Rheumatic fever and was planned to start with penicillin injections. A test dose was given in antecubital fossa after which there was redness and swelling in the area withing 15 minutes. Which of the following cell is most likely leading to such a manifestation?

A child is having multiple petechiae and purpura on the skin, abdominal cramps for last 3 days. He had a bout of respiratory tract infection prior to onset of these symptoms. Now the patient presents to you with reduced urine output for last 24 hours and pedal edema. urine examination shows many RBC and RBC casts. IF shows IgA deposits along the endothelium. A renal biopsy is as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

An 8-month-old male infant is admitted to the hospital because of a bacterial respiratory infection. The infant responds to appropriate anti- biotic therapy but is readmitted several weeks later because of severe otitis media. Over the next several months, the infant is admitted to the hospital multiple times for recurrent bacterial infections. Workup reveals extremely low serum antibody levels. The infant has no previous history of viral or fungal infections. The most likely diagnosis for this infant is
Worst prognostic histological type of breast carcinoma is
Most consistent histological finding in COVID lung is
A medical student is describing histology of an anaplastic carcinoma of thyroid, which of the following histological feature is not applicable for features of anaplasia in this patient?

A 23-year-old woman has presented with headache not relieved by NSAIDs for last few weeks now she is having diminished vision. Her Hb is 18g/dl, RBC count 7.5 million AND HEMATOCRIT IS 52%. Physical examination revealed 6th and 8th nerve palsy. Fundoscopy revealed bilateral papilledema and increased in retinal vessels which are dilated tortuous. Imaging of brain shows a tumor in the cerebellum. Which mutation is likely to be seen in this patient?
A 10-year-old boy presents with bleeding per rectum. Colonoscopy shows a polyp and excision was done. Histological examination is as shown below. Which of the following is likely diagnosis?

A 56-year-old smoker had cough, past 3 weeks although he has completely stopped smoking since then. He has vomiting, fatigue, weigh loss of 6 kg. he acts confused and is not oriented to place and time. A blood examination shows serum sodium 115mEq/L, calcium levels are normal. Chest CT shows a small lesion in the wall of the peri hilar bronchus and a few perihilar lymph nodes. Histology is as shown in the image. Which of the following is correct explanation of this patient’s manifestations?

options.label: A
options.text: Squamous cell carcinoma with intracranial metastasis

options.label: B
options.text: Squamous cell carcinoma with a paraneoplastic manifestation

options.label: C
options.text: Small cell carcinoma with intracranial metastasis

options.label: D
options.text: Small cell carcinoma with paraneoplastic manifestations

questions.correct_answer: D. Small cell carcinoma with paraneoplastic manifestations

questions.text: An eight-year-old child is having repeated diarrhoea. Blood examination shows Dimorphic anemia. The child’s daily diet consists of meat, fruits, green leafy vegetables, and roti (wheat bread). Biopsy from duodenum is as shown in the image. Which of the following is most likely cause of the peripheral blood finding in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Folic acid and iron deficiency

questions.text: A 78-year-old had abdominal aneurysm rupture, which was surgically repaired he was transfused 3 units of packed RBC and 1 unit of FFP. During next unit of blood transfusion, the patient develops breathlessness, O2 saturation is 86%, pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate 28/min, BP 120/80. Auscultation reveals bilateral crepitations, a clinical diagnosis of pulmonary edema secondary to blood transfusion was made. The patient is given inhalational oxygen and bronchodilators. Which of the following additional treatment is required in this patient?

A 6-year-old boy presents with unilateral proptosis. Imaging shows mass behind the eye near the optic nerve. Histological examination is as shown in the image. the tumor is negative for Desmin, S-100 but positive for GFAP. What is the likely diagnosis?
